page.title: 08Farming
page.content: We interviewed two farmers whose families have farmed in the area for over 50 years. They have very different ways of farming even though they have about the same acre-age. The first uses most of his land for arable farming, planting wheat, barley, sugar beet, peas and oilseed rape. He retains about 30 acres for bullocks which he buys in annually and sells as fatstock. He has removed a number of hedges to make larger expanses of land, though he has planted copses of deciduous trees to give shade to his cattle. The second farmer also divides his land between livestock and arable but this is nearer to half and half. He grows oats, barley, oilseed rape and swede. He retains large areas of traditional meadow land where he grazes cattle, some of which he breeds and some of which is sold for beef.
